TopicTitle: Am I allowed to have multiple installs of KSP?

Articles.Content: If I for some reason want to use 2 (or more) copies of KSP (with different set of addons), would it be legal? Should I buy additional copies?

I am not a lawyer, etc. 

But the EULA is online at [https://kerbalspaceprogram.com/eula.php](https://kerbalspaceprogram.com/eula.php) , and section 1 seems to be pretty clear about letting you keep multiple concurrent installations, as well as backup copies. 

Personally, I have the game installed on two or three computers. They're all only played by me, and obviously only one at a time. I'm comfortable that I'm not violating the spirit of the licence. And almost definitely not the letter of the licence either
Copy, paste, do whatever the hell you want.
Worry less about what's legal or not. Who are you harming with your multiple copies? And who's going to find out or really care?

I think of a KSP license as a "seat" license. As long as only one person is playing it at a time you can do what you like. I personally keep several installs, and in the past I kept my install in my dropbox where it was synced to multiple computers.

Disclaimer: I am not a lawyer, and I am not Squad's lawyer or employee.

They're not going to care about you having a few installs.

If you're really worried, have separate gamedata folders in the same filepath as your main install.

Well, CKAN for one. It supports managing the mods in multiple installs. There's also that map view multi-monitor mod, which actually requires a second instance of KSP to be running simultaneously.

You can have as many installations of KSP on your computer as you want.

You can have a roommate come over and play it on your computer or take it with you to a LAN-party.

What you can't do, is burn the disc and then sell, lend, lease or any other combination therein to other people. 

*By disc, I am referring to your copy of KSP*

Yeah, the EULA is pretty permissive, unlike your typical MS/EA/Sony/Google big-corporate nonsense we-own-your-firstborn EULA. As long as you aren't giving away or selling your copy, you're probably fine.
